DOC.HEAD: Panel Suggests Way Out of Noriega Dilemma
Eds: Subs final grafs 10-12, `Anderson said...' to CORRECT spelling to Andersen.
With PM-Panama, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Vatican should put the fate of ousted Panamanian Gen. Manuel Noriega in the hands of a special public tribunal, a group of American scholars suggested. In a statement transmitted this week to the Vatican, nine U.S. legal experts and academicians said turning Noriega over to a ``grand-jury-type panel'' would set a positive precedent in international criminal law for handling deposed dictators accused of criminal activity. The panel should be made up of ``distinguished persons publicly known to be of high integrity and fair-mindedness, selected by yourselves and others, including the secretary general of the United Nations,'' the statement said. Noriega has been holed up in the Vatican embassy in Panama City since Sunday. Both U.S. and Panamanian officials have urged the Vatican to turn him over for trial on drug-trafficking charges. Alfred F. Andersen, a self-described retired philosopher and author who lives in Tucson, said in a telephone interview Thursday that he and the eight others who signed the document believe it would be a mistake for the Vatican simply to hand Noriega over to the United States. ``We, the undersigned, commend your not making a hasty decision in this matter, and your evidently wanting to be sure that your ultimate decision will truly serve the cause of justice in this turbulent world,'' the statement said Andersen said the statement was his idea. ``I saw the dilemma the Vatican was in,'' Andersen said. ``I started thinking about how he could be turned over to someone who would be more objective than the United States or even the Panamanian government.'' Andersen said he contacted a friend, Richard A. Falk, a Princeton University international law professor, and the two of them worked out the statement. Andersen said he and Falk then contacted the others whose names appear on the document transmitted to the Vatican Wednesday night and again on Thursday. The Vatican has yet to respond, Andersen said. In addition to himself and Falk, Andersen said the statement also was signed by Benjamin B. Ferenca, a prosecutor at the Nuremberg trials following World War II, who now lives in New Rochelle, N.Y.; Burns H. Weston, a University of Iowa law professor; Stephen Cary, retired vice president of Haverford College, Haverford, Penn.; Hazel Henderson, an author, St. Augustine, Fla.; Gerald Mische, president of Global Education Associates, New York; and Saul Mendlovitz, director of World Order Models Project, New York.
